thread.title: 12 of the world's top spots to get close to animals in the wild and in captivity
thread.title_full: 12 of the world's top spots to get close to animals in the wild and in captivity | Travel | Travel News and Holiday Deals | | The Advertiser

author: Andy van Smeerdijk
title: 12 of the world's top spots to get close to animals in the wild and in captivity
text:
1. Aussie Wildlife
Sunshine Coast, Queensland
It was wildlife campaigner Steve Irwin’s dream – a place people could mingle with critters and have their photo taken with them. Priding itself on “animal encounters”, Australia Zoo, run by Irwin’s family, allows visitors to get close to koalas, wombats and various native animals plus tortoises, lemurs, rhinos and even tigers. While tiger encounters are restricted to those aged 15 and over, children aged six-14 are welcome to enjoy possum encounters.
australiazoo.com.au
 Dusky dolphin jumping high off the coast of Kaikoura, New Zealand. Picture: iStock Source: Supplied
2. Dolphins
New Zealand
You don’t have to venture too far from Australia to enjoy wildlife. Boat operators at Kaikoura, in New Zealand’s South Island, offer trips for adults and children to go swimming with dolphins. Peter Allison, a safari guide who went on a trip where dolphins interacted with visitors, says it’s an amazing experience that is literally immersive. Clad in wetsuits, children aged eight-14 can paddle among the dolphins, while kids aged three and over can watch the fun from the boat. At times, visitors can swim with pods of up to 100 dolphins.
www.dolphinencounter.co.nz
 Polar bears in Canada. Picture: iStock Source: Supplied
3. Polar Bears
Canada
Wildlife guide Carol Walton has been bringing tourists to see polar bears in Churchill, Canada, for 18 years.
“Each trip we see between 25 and 45 polar bears, often up close and personal from the comfort of a tundra buggy,” she says.
October to mid-November is the time to visit as the bears arrive to wait for ice to form on Hudson’s Bay to hunt seals. Churchill is one of the few towns where polar bears can be seen in the wild. On many tours, kids eight and over are welcome.
churchillwild.com
4. Animal-mania
San Diego Zoo, US
San Diego Zoo is no ordinary zoo. Where else could you enjoy an early morning get-together with pandas? Or feed biscuits to giraffes? The Backstage Pass tour includes close encounters with animals, allowing visitors to pose in photos with some of them.
There’s even a tour called KinderTots, specialising in early childhood education; highlights include New Guinea singing dogs and wombats.
North of here is San Diego Zoo Safari Park, where visitors can go on game drives to see rhinos, giraffes, lions, elephants, cheetahs and tigers. All kids are welcome, with children under two allowed in free.
zoo.sandiegozoo.org , sdzsafaripark.org
 Gallapagos Islands is a great place to see giant tortoises. Picture: iStock Source: Supplied
5. Tortoises
Galapagos Islands
Off the coast of Ecuador, these islands are alive with creatures including giant Galapagos tortoises, which barely react when people walk up to them.
Ted Martens, of Natural Habitat Adventures, which does family trips with kids seven and over, says the Galapagos Islands are great for younger folks because the wildlife is so prolific, friendly and approachable.
Carol Walton agrees: “The animals are totally tame and you have to literally almost step over them. Sea lions play with you when you’re snorkelling, marine iguanas just sit there and you can get close-ups of their faces. Galapagos penguins will also swim around you.”
peregrineadventures.com nathab.com/family-adventures
6. Chilled critters Antarctica
Cruising to Antarctica from South America? Many guides recommend trips that include stops at South Georgia Island and the Falklands. Former guide Heidi Dormody advises a cruise via both, saying this trip is suitable for children 10 and over. “There you will see several varieties of penguins, elephant seals, whales and albatross.” South Georgia Island has incredible wildlife, Carol Walton says. “There is a beach with 500,000 king penguins. There are elephant seals, fur seals, and albatrosses, in addition to king penguins, gentoo penguins and macaroni penguins.” She says Antarctica is otherworldly with seals, whales, penguins plus majestic snow-covered mountains and blue icebergs.
zegrahm.com , carolwaltonexpeditions.com
 See a lion up close in Namibia. Picture: iStock Source: Supplied
7. Lions
Namibia
Want to see lions up close? One safari lodge near Ongava Game Reserve in Namibia lets you and your children watch predators from hides. Rob Moffett, from Ongava, says Andersson’s Camp photo hide has an underground access tunnel from inside the camp so guests and kids can come and go at leisure. Children older than six are welcome at Andersson’s Camp, though those aged six-16 must share a room with an adult. The minimum age for walking safaris is 13.
ongava.com , wilderness-safaris.com
 Meercats in their element in Botswana. Picture: iStock Source: Supplied
8. Meerkats
Botswana
Jack’s Camp, a safari lodge near the Kalahari, is the spot for meerkats. Observed by researchers then visited by tourists for more than 20 years, these tiny, habituated mammals are at ease with humans and often climb up to stand atop visitors’ shoulders and heads.
Brown hyenas, ground squirrels and antelopes such as springbok and oryx are often seen here. Children under eight will require the family taking a separate vehicle.
abercrombiekent.com.au
9. Penguins
Cape Town
Boulders Beach near Cape Town is home to more than 2000 endangered African penguins that surf the waves, nest near the beach and are incredibly relaxed with humans, despite being close to one of South Africa’s biggest cities. With admission about $4 (kids 2-11, $2), there’s a beach and three boardwalks for visitors. While the penguins are accustomed to humans, touching them is prohibited.
capetown.travel
 Lemur in Madagascar. Picture: iStock Source: Supplied
10. Dancing lemurs
Madagascar
Situated 150km from the capital of Madagascar, Antananarivo, Andasibe-Mantadia National Park is one of the top reserves at which to view lemurs. On a guided walk through Mantadia, you may spot Verreaux’s sifaka lemur dancing through the trees or hopping along on their hind feet. The best option for kids is Vakona Lodge, Lemur Island, where visitors can get friendly with lemurs relocated from orphanages around Madagascar. It’s a great photo opportunity for lemurs, some of which sit on visitors’ shoulders. At Anamalazotra and VOI Community Park you’ll find the indri lemurs, famous for their singing.
starry-starry-nights.com
11. Pandas
China
In the city of Chengdu in China, the Panda Research & Breeding Centre enables visitors to get close to these endangered animals. It includes a juvenile section where you can take photos of pandas aged one to five snoozing, chewing bamboo and playing. You can also view pandas in the adult area, including the smaller red pandas in the trees. At the Dujiangyan Giant Panda Centre, a breeding and research centre also in Chengdu, visitors can get their photo taken while holding baby pandas, aged between six months and one year old. Money spent on this goes to research.
abercrombiekent.com.au , viator.com
12. Monkey magic
Bali
Beware, there’s a forest near Ubud where monkeys steal visitors’ snacks and leap on their backpacks, but if you’re careful, they’ll soon have you in stitches at their naughty behaviour.
South of Ubud, Monkey Forest is full of temples but the long-tailed macaques tend to dominate interest.
“Do not carry any food,” local Wayan warns. “If they charge, stand your ground. Step back and they’ll jump on you.”
Once they know you’re monkey-canny, they’ll leave you alone, he says.
monkeyforestubud.com
HOW TO CHOOSE
Before booking a wildlife holiday, researching the safety standards of your tour or camp and whether it caters for children is vital.
Ted Martens, from Natural Habitat Adventures, recommends choosing a tour operator that specialises in family trips.
“If it’s not something that they advertise that they do, then chances are they haven't put the thought into all of the nuances that families require,” he says.
“That specialised interpretation is key to keeping the kids entertained — and the parents sane!”
